paragraphs.paragraphContent: The first step is to determine if you qualify for an FSA Farm Loan.
Our short questionnaire will help you learn whether you meet the basic eligibility qualifications for our loans.
Click the button below to determine your eligibility.

steps.subtitle: Eligibility Self Assessment
steps.title: Are you eligible for an FSA loan?

paragraphs.paragraphContent: In the last four years, have you been convicted for planting, cultivating, growing, producing, harvesting, storing, trafficking, or possessing controlled substances?
Applicants are not eligible for FSA loans if convicted under Federal or State law for planting, cultivating, growing, producing, harvesting, or storing a controlled substance.
However, if the applicant can provide documentation that the conviction was more than 4 years ago, then he or she may be eligible.
You indicated that you have a recent drug conviction.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Do you (or anyone who will sign the promissory note) have the legal competency to enter into a loan agreement?
All applicants must be of legal age and have the mental capacity to receive a Direct Loan. Each applicant must have the authority to sign a legally binding contract.
You indicated that you are unable to sign a legally binding agreement
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Are you a United States citizen, non-citizen national or legal resident alien of the United States?
Applicants born in American Samoa and Swains Island are considered U.S. non-citizens and will require documentation to meet eligibility.

Qualified aliens who are lawfully admitted for permanent residence under the Immigration and Nationality Act will be eligible. Additional information will be needed to document qualified alien status.
Qualified aliens are defined as follows:
You indicated that you may not meet the citizenship requirement.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Do you have an acceptable credit history demonstrating timely payments?

While FSA does not consider credit scores as a determining factor, our agency evaluates credit history and determines whether the applicant has a history of making payments as they come due. The applicant will be deemed ineligible if FSA notes a general pattern of past due or delinquent payments, with the exception of circumstances beyond the applicant’s control.
You indicated that you may not meet the credit history requirement, demonstrating on-time payments.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Are you able to obtain alternative financing through a commercial lender?

To meet this requirement, applicants must be unable to receive financing from a commercial lending institution. If an applicant has not applied for credit elsewhere, after reviewing the application, FSA will determine if there is a possibility that the applicant is able to receive credit elsewhere.
You indicated that you may be able to receive financing from a commercial lender.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Do you have delinquent federal debts or unpaid federal judgements, other than IRS tax debt?
Applicants who are delinquent on any federal debts or have any unpaid federal judgments are ineligible.
However, applicants may become eligible if they are able to pay in full or resolve the delinquent federal debt or judgment before loan closing.
IRS tax debt does not apply but may be used to evaluate credit worthiness.
You indicated that you have delinquent federal debts or unpaid federal judgements.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Have you ever been forgiven of a past debt by FSA?
Applicants who have been forgiven of a past FSA loan will be considered ineligible for Direct Loan Assistance unless they have extenuating circumstances such as:

bullets.bulletContent: Received a debt reduction through a conservation easement or contract.
Had a debt written off as a part of the resolution for a discrimination complaint against the Farm Service Agency.
Had a prior debt forgiven that has been repaid entirely.
Had a debt forgiven on a Youth Loan for circumstances beyond the applicant’s control.

paragraphs.paragraphContent: You indicated that you have been forgiven for a past FSA loan.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Are you disqualified as a result of a Federal Crop Insurance violation?
Applicants who willfully and intentionally provide false or inaccurate information to FCIC or to any approved insurance provider with respect to a policy or plan will be ineligible.
You indicated that you may be disqualified as a result of a Federal Crop Insurance violation.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Do you have prior farming experience or relevant training?
The applicant must demonstrate sufficient managerial ability to assure reasonable prospects of loan repayment, as determined by FSA.
You indicated that you may lack sufficient farm management experience.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Will you be the operator of a family farm?
After the loan has closed, the applicant must be the operator of the farm. Applicants must make the management and operating decisions for the farm and not a third-party entity.
You indicated that you will not be the operator of a family farm.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Are you applying as a non-profit organization?
Non-Profit Organizations (NPO) are not eligible to receive FSA loan assistance.
You indicated that you are applying as a Non-Profit Organization.
Based on your response to this question, you may not be eligible for FSA loans.
If you believe that you have special circumstances that might allow for an exception, contact your local FSA office for instructions.
Based on your responses to the self assessment you may meet the basic eligibility requirements to proceed. Click the button below to discover which FSA loans are right for you.

FSA offers various loan programs including Youth Loans, Emergency Loans, Microloans, Farm Ownership Loans, and Operating Loans. While FSA is committed to serving all farmers and ranchers, by statute, FSA targets a portion of all Guaranteed loan funds, Microloan funding, and Youth loans, to historically underserved farmers and ranchers.

The following screens will take you through a series of questions to find the loan product that is right for you and provide you with a checklist of the documents you will need to begin the loan application process.
Click the button below to discover the loans that align with your circumstances.

steps.subtitle: Loan Discovery
steps.title: Which Loans Are Right For You?

paragraphs.paragraphContent: FSA makes loans to young people to start and operate income-producing projects of modest size in connection with their participation in 4-H clubs, FFA, Tribal youth groups, or similar agricultural youth organizations.
For a project to be eligible for a Youth Loan, it needs to provide an opportunity for the young person to acquire experience and education in agriculture-related skills.
Are you seeking financial assistance with an educational agricultural project?

To qualify for a FSA Youth Loan, you must be between the ages of 10 and 20 at the time of the loan closing. You must be seeking a loan for educational purposes, up to $5,000. You will need to have a Project Advisor/Sponsor and the consent of a parent or legal guardian.
Note: If you are over 18 years of age, and seeking more than $5,000, you may qualify for other FSA loans.
Your Next Steps
IMPORTANT: Make sure you have gathered all documentation before proceeding with the loan forms.

bullets.bulletContent: Download and print out the Readiness Checklist for the Youth Loan Program.
Gather the necessary loan application forms and documentation from the checklist.
Fill out and submit your forms.

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Are you seeking an Emergency Loan for a loss associated with a natural disaster or emergency declaration?

steps.subtitle: Associated with a Natural Disaster of Emergency Declaration
steps.title: Emergency Loans

paragraphs.paragraphContent: The Emergency Loan Program is triggered when a natural disaster is designated by the Secretary of Agriculture, or a natural disaster or emergency is declared by the President under the Stafford Act. These loans help producers who suffer qualifying farm related losses directly caused by the disaster in a county declared or designated as a primary disaster or quarantine area. Also, farmers located in counties that are contiguous to the declared, designated, or quarantined area may qualify for Emergency loans.

For production losses, a 30% reduction in a primary crop in a designated or contiguous county is required. Losses to quality, such as receiving a 30% reduced price for flood damaged crops, may be eligible for assistance, too.

steps.subtitle: Associated with a Natural Disaster of Emergency Declaration
steps.title: Emergency Loans

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Your Next Steps
IMPORTANT: Make sure you have gathered all documentation before proceeding with the loan forms.

bullets.bulletContent: Download and print out the Readiness Checklist for the Youth Loan Program.
Gather the necessary loan application forms and documentation from the checklist.
Fill out and submit your forms.

steps.subtitle: Associated with a Natural Disaster of Emergency Declaration
steps.title: Emergency Loans

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Are you seeking a loan amount less than or equal to $50,000?

The focus of Microloans is on the financing needs of small, beginning farmer, niche and non-traditional farm operations, such as truck farms, farms participating in direct marketing and sales such as farmers’ markets, CSA’s (Community Supported Agriculture), restaurants, and grocery stores, or those using hydroponic, aquaponic, organic and vertical growing methods.

There is no minimum loan amount. You may request up to $50,000 for a Farm Ownership Microloan and up to an additional $50,000 for an Operating Microloan. The $50,000 limit includes any possible outstanding FSA Direct Operating or Farm Ownership unpaid principal loan balances. A loan applicant may have a Guaranteed Operating Loan, Farm Ownership loan or Emergency Loan and still qualify for a Microloan.
Need More Capital? Consider a Farm Ownership or Operating Loan.
Your Next Steps
IMPORTANT: Make sure you have gathered all documentation before proceeding with the loan forms.

bullets.bulletContent: Download and print out the Readiness Checklist for the Youth Loan Program.
Gather the necessary loan application forms and documentation from the checklist.
Fill out and submit your forms.

paragraphs.paragraphContent: What is the purpose of the loan you are seeking?

steps.subtitle: For Farm Ownership and Operating Expenses
steps.title: Direct Loans

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Farm Ownership Loans may be used to purchase a farm, enlarge an existing farm, construct new farm buildings and/or improve structures, pay closing costs, and promote soil and water conservation and protection.
Note: Farm Ownership Loans can be used in combination with other FSA and commercial loan products to meet your total financing need.

steps.subtitle: To Purchase or Enlarge Family Flans
steps.title: Farm Ownership Loans

paragraphs.paragraphContent: There are three types of Farm Ownership Loans:

bullets.bulletContent: Down Payment Loans – The applicant must make a down payment of at least 5% of the purchase price
Joint Financing Loans – No down payment required, but at least 50% of the purchase price must be financed by a commercial lender or contract for deed holder.
Direct Farm Ownership Loans – No down payment required; FSA can finance up to 100% of the appraised value up to the loan limit.

steps.subtitle: To Purchase or Enlarge Family Farms
steps.title: Farm Ownership Loans

buttons.buttonText: Proceed with a Down Payment Loan

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Down Payment Loans assist socially disadvantaged, military veterans, and beginning farmers in purchasing a farm.
Requirements:
Your Next Steps
IMPORTANT: Make sure you have gathered all documentation before proceeding with the loan forms.

bullets.bulletContent: Download and print out the Readiness Checklist for the Youth Loan Program.
Gather the necessary loan application forms and documentation from the checklist.
Fill out and submit your forms.

buttons.buttonText: Proceed with a Joint Financing Loan

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Joint Financing Loans may be used to purchase a farm, enlarge an existing farm, construct new farm buildings and/or improve structures, pay closing costs, and promote soil and water conservation and protection.
Requirements:

bullets.bulletContent: No down payment required.
At least 50% of the purchase price must be financed by a commercial lender or contract for deed holder.

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Your Next Steps
IMPORTANT: Make sure you have gathered all documentation before proceeding with the loan forms.

bullets.bulletContent: Download and print out the Readiness Checklist for the Youth Loan Program.
Gather the necessary loan application forms and documentation from the checklist.
Fill out and submit your forms.

buttons.buttonText: Proceed with a Direct Farm Ownership Loan

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Direct Farm Ownership Loans offer up to 100 percent financing and are a valuable resource to help farmers and ranchers purchase or enlarge family farms, improve and expand current operations, increase agricultural productivity, and assist with land tenure to save farmland for future generations. It has a maximum loan amount of $600,000.
Your Next Steps
IMPORTANT: Make sure you have gathered all documentation before proceeding with the loan forms.

bullets.bulletContent: Download and print out the Readiness Checklist for the Youth Loan Program.
Gather the necessary loan application forms and documentation from the checklist.
Fill out and submit your forms.

buttons.buttonText: Proceed with a Term Operating Loan

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Farm Operating Loans may be used for normal operating expenses, machinery and equipment, minor real estate repairs or improvements, and refinancing debt. The direct loans are available up to a maximum of $400,000.
FSA will guarantee farm operating loans through a commercial leader up to $1,776,000. The repayment term may vary, but it cannot exceed seven years.
Direct operating loans require applicants to have sufficient education, training, or at least one year’s experience in managing or operating a farm or ranch within the last five years.

steps.subtitle: Terminal Loans of Up to 7 Years
steps.title: Term Operating Loans

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Your Next Steps
IMPORTANT: Make sure you have gathered all documentation before proceeding with the loan forms.

bullets.bulletContent: Download and print out the Readiness Checklist for the Youth Loan Program.
Gather the necessary loan application forms and documentation from the checklist.
Fill out and submit your forms.

steps.subtitle: Terminal Loans of Up to 7 Years
steps.title: Term Operating Loans

buttons.buttonText: Proceed with an Annual Operating Loan

paragraphs.paragraphContent: Farm Operating Loans may be used for normal operating expenses, machinery and equipment, minor real estate repairs or improvements, and refinancing debt. The direct loans are available up to a maximum of $400,000. FSA will guarantee farm operating loans through a commercial leader up to $1,776,000.
Annual operating loans are generally repaid within 12 months or when the commodities produced are sold.
Direct operating loans require applicants to have sufficient education, training, or at least one year’s experience in managing or operating a farm or ranch within the last five years.
Your Next Steps
IMPORTANT: Make sure you have gathered all documentation before proceeding with the loan forms.

bullets.bulletContent: Download and print out the Readiness Checklist for the Youth Loan Program.
Gather the necessary loan application forms and documentation from the checklist.
Fill out and submit your forms.
